[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to policy-and-docs-in-code'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:56:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-07 01:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-07 03:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-07 03:43:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This would be going a lot faster if the WiFi here were good enough to populate a local virtualenv for testing :/'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-07 07:51:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-08 04:05:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-13 00:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Comment inline about moving two of the policy definitions.

The tasks test failures require https://review.opendev.org/693952

Not sure, but you may also need https://review.opendev.org/693951 so that the tests will run reliably.

The PropertyRules tests may require some finessing with the policy enforcer.  (Glance uses the oslo policy engine to enforce ACLs on individual image properties; it doesn't make sense for these to have defaults.)  The failures are caused by oslo_policy.policy.PolicyNotRegistered exceptions.  I haven't had time to look into these."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-13 13:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@Zane: Here's an outline of the problems we'll face trying to align the Glance policies with the rest of OpenStack: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/528021/"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-13 18:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Yeah, I read that spec and it certainly blocks getting the documentation into code (which is part of the goal), but not getting the policies defined in code (which is the part that is blocking future project-wide goals, and also a pre-requisite to you changing the policies around).'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-14 14:03:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

To address the failure in glance.tests.unit.test_policy.TestPolicyEnforcer:

I think you'll need to remove test_policy_file_get_image_default_nobody and test_policy_file_get_image_default_everybody.  Those test what happens on image-show when there's only the "default" policy defined.  With the policies defined in code, I believe this isn't possible any more (that is, that there is no policy associated with "image_get" action).'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-14 17:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Wait, does that mean that the defaults for each policy should be "rule:default" rather than ""?

I'm confused at what those DEFAULT_POLICIES are for in general since they're not referenced anywhere. e.g. why does "publicize_image" default to "role:admin" and not "rule:context_is_admin", and what is the purpose of defining the context_is_admin rule when it's not used?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-14 17:36:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-14 19:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-14 19:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Wait, does that mean that the defaults for each policy should be
> "rule:default" rather than ""?

No, I don't think so.  Those tests were added when we changed "default":"" to "default":"role:admin" in the policy file, I guess to illustrate what happens when the "default" action is the only policy mentioned in the policy file.  If we make the default for each policy "rule:default" and then had "default":"role:admin" in the DEFAULT_POLICIES, operators would be forced to configure a policy file to allow end users to do anything, which I think goes against the sensible defaults in code idea?

> I'm confused at what those DEFAULT_POLICIES are for in general since
> they're not referenced anywhere. e.g. why does "publicize_image"
> default to "role:admin" and not "rule:context_is_admin", and what
> is the purpose of defining the context_is_admin rule when it's not used?

context_is_admin is used to set an is_admin flag on the context object, where it's used at various points to decide things like "should this user be allowed to see images in a project they don't belong to?" for which there aren't policies.  So like you'd expect from the name, it defines the administrative context.

I'm not sure exactly why we prefer "role:admin" in the policy file, probably just for simplicity.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-14 19:25:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

OK, cool, that aligns with what I independently figured out, and it's reflected in the latest patchset (removed the default rule + tests for it, and documented the is_admin_context rule)."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-14 21:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-11-15 14:56:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+2

This looks right to me based on what I've seen done elsewhere.

It would be good to get this merged early in the release so we have some time for it to bake before the end of the cycle, just in case we find any unintended side-effects or something that wasn't converted quite right."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-22 14:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

I have no objections, but would like Abhishek and/or Erno to approve.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-05 14:52:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

Bumping to +2 because I approve of this change, but I'd really like Abhishek or Erno to approve it."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-12-06 05:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I like this change, just wanted to have a unit test for the exception raised if policy is not registered to ensure it is covered.

Thank you Zane for taking this up!!!'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-06 12:56:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thanks Zane,

Most parts this looks fine. I have couple of concerns inline regarding the policy file handling, I might have overlooked somewhere as I did not see the policy-file we're looking for changing with this ps.

My bigger concern is that I also don't see us testing anywhere the point 3 of the goal completion criteria [0]. As in that we still prioritize the overrides by the policy file provided. (I need to have a look, we might have actual functional tests covering this.)

[0] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html#completion-criteria"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-06 15:11:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)

> My bigger concern is that I also don't see us testing anywhere the point 3 of the goal completion criteria [0]. As in that we still prioritize the overrides by the policy file provided.

I believe that this is covered by the existing tests."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-06 15:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:23:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> We cannot just silently ignore "default" rule that applies everywhere and has been the basis for any sane policy file so far.

That's only true if you look at Glance in isolation.  For all the other major services, using "default" in this way became impossible in Queens.  No one's been able to use an abbreviated file like the one you illustrated above for OpenStack services in general since Pike, so I don't think it's plausible that operators would expect to be able to use the "default" rule as the basis of any sane policy file so far.  Since Queens, operator expectations (for all the other services, anyway) have been that you can run without a policy file and have sane defaults, and if you want anything different, you have to run with a custom file, but you only need to mention the policies that you want to behave differently from the default behavior.  Actions that go unmentioned in the file are expected to behave according to the sane default defined in the code, not according to the "default" policy.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

Question for Lance inline.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:54:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

One thing we could do is to reinstate the 'default' rule but with the check_str set to "", then change the check_str of all of the non-admin default rules to "rule:default". If we did that then your example:

  {
    "context_is_admin": "role:admin",
    "default": "role:admin",
    "get_image": "",
    "get_images": "",
    "download_image": "",
    "get_image_location": ""
  }

would work as expected. However, if a user relied on the default 'default' for some of their defaults (!), like so:

  {
    "context_is_admin": "role:admin",
    "get_image": "",
    "get_images": "",
    "download_image": "",
    "get_image_location": ""
  }

then that would not work the same as before; they'd still get the default "" policy on those rules with non-admin default that they did not specifically override, whereas previously the default 'default' was "role:admin".

(Glance and Keystone seem to be the only projects that used an admin-only rule as the default 'default' rule.)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-12-06 20:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-06 22:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

We could also add an upgrade checker to check for policy.json files that will change meaning after an upgrade.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 02:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-12-12 05:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-12-12 06:42:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Tempest is failing while creating image with 403 error due to this change.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 14:19:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Workflow-1

"Failed to understand rule  or role:admin: ValueError: Could not parse rule"

So oslo_policy can't handle it if you deprecate a rule and replace it with "" :/
I'll eliminate the deprecation bit, and then we can fix oslo_policy and add it back in again later.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 19:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-16 14:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-17 12:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2

Thanks Zane!

I can live with this.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-12-17 14:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Thanks, Zane.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-19 14:18:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think the concept is fine, but I find the 'security' section of the release note confusing and possibly inaccurate."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-19 20:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-12-20 02:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-06 18:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-06 18:02:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-01-07 06:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-01-09 10:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

'}, {'created': '2019-11-14 19:03:25.000000000', 'message': "Move policy defaults into code

Instead of a default policy.json file, policy defaults are now defined
in code. An operator need not supply policy.json data except to the
extent they want to override the defaults. Currently an empty
policy.json is still shipped because it is expected by devstack, but
this can be removed later. A sample policy.yaml file can be generated
using the genpolicy tox environment.

This partly fulfils the requirements of the policy in code goal[1].
However, because policies don't map 1:1 with APIs, it will not be
possible to fully document the policies until changes are made in how
policies are applied as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/528021

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html

Change-Id: I8d1ccf5844078cc0b1652fb1130794daf07cedbc
"}, {'created': '2019-11-14 21:40:22.000000000', 'message': "Move policy defaults into code

Instead of a default policy.json file, policy defaults are now defined
in code. An operator need not supply policy.json data except to the
extent they want to override the defaults. Currently an empty
policy.json is still shipped because it is expected by devstack, but
this can be removed later. A sample policy.yaml file can be generated
using the genpolicy tox environment.

This partly fulfils the requirements of the policy in code goal[1].
However, because policies don't map 1:1 with APIs, it will not be
possible to fully document the policies until changes are made in how
policies are applied as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/528021

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html

Change-Id: I8d1ccf5844078cc0b1652fb1130794daf07cedbc
"}, {'created': '2019-12-12 02:56:28.000000000', 'message': 'Move policy defaults into code

Instead of a default policy.json file, policy defaults are now defined
in code. An operator need not supply policy.json data except to the
extent they want to override the defaults. Currently an empty
policy.json is still shipped because it is expected by devstack, but
this can be removed later. A sample policy.yaml file can be generated
using the genpolicy tox environment.

This partly fulfils the requirements of the policy in code goal[1].
However, because policies don't map 1:1 with APIs, it will not be
possible to fully document the policies until changes are made in how
policies are applied as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/528021

Due to the fact that existing policy files may rely on a rule named
"default" to specifiy policies not explicitly listed in the policy.json
file, all policies that are not admin-only by default now default to
"rule:default", so that the "default" rule will continue to apply to
those policies that are not listed in policy.json.

To ensure that this yields the expected policy in a standard
policy-in-code config file, the default value of the "default" rule is
now the empty string "". This is a change; between the Queens release
and now the default was set to "role:admin" to match the value specified
in the default policy.json file. An installation relying on both the
"default" rule for some policies and the default value of the default
rule may end up with a more permissive policy after upgrading. It's
likely that no such policies exist in the wild, because prior to the
Queens release the default value for the "default" rule was "@" (allow
all requests), so anybody relying on this rule will surely have
specified it explicitly in their policy.json.

Policies whose default is "role:admin" no longer use the "default" rule.
Therefore existing policy.json files that rely on the "default" rule for
those policies, and who have specified a value for the "default" rule
that is more permissive, will result in a more restrictive policy after
upgrading. It is unlikely that any of these policies exist in the wild
either.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html

Change-Id: I8d1ccf5844078cc0b1652fb1130794daf07cedbc
'}, {'created': '2019-12-12 19:45:01.000000000', 'message': 'Move policy defaults into code

To ensure that this yields the expected policy in a standard

'}, {'created': '2019-12-16 14:33:59.000000000', 'message': 'Move policy defaults into code

Instead of a default policy.json file, policy defaults are now defined
in code. An operator need not supply policy.json data except to the
extent they want to override the defaults. Currently an empty
policy.json is still shipped because it is expected by devstack, but
this can be removed later. A sample policy.yaml file can be generated
using the genpolicy tox environment.

This partly fulfils the requirements of the policy in code goal[1].
However, because policies don't map 1:1 with APIs, it will not be
possible to fully document the policies until changes are made in how
policies are applied as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/528021

Due to the fact that existing policy files may rely on a rule named
"default" to specifiy policies not explicitly listed in the policy.json
file, all policies that are not admin-only by default now default to
"rule:default", so that the "default" rule will continue to apply to
those policies that are not listed in policy.json.

To ensure that this yields the expected policy in a standard
policy-in-code config file, the default value of the "default" rule is
now the empty string "". This is a change; between the Queens release
and now the default was set to "role:admin" to match the value specified
in the default policy.json file. An installation relying on both the
"default" rule for some policies and the default value of the default
rule may end up with a more permissive policy after upgrading. It's
likely that no such policies exist in the wild, because prior to the
Queens release the default value for the "default" rule was "@" (allow
all requests), so anybody relying on this rule will surely have
specified it explicitly in their policy.json.

Policies whose default is "role:admin" no longer use the "default" rule.
Therefore existing policy.json files that rely on the "default" rule for
those policies, and who have specified a value for the "default" rule
that is more permissive, will result in a more restrictive policy after
upgrading. It is unlikely that any of these policies exist in the wild
either.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html

Change-Id: I8d1ccf5844078cc0b1652fb1130794daf07cedbc

commit_message:
Move policy defaults into code

Instead of a default policy.json file, policy defaults are now defined
in code. An operator need not supply policy.json data except to the
extent they want to override the defaults. Currently an empty
policy.json is still shipped because it is expected by devstack, but
this can be removed later. A sample policy.yaml file can be generated
using the genpolicy tox environment.

This partly fulfils the requirements of the policy in code goal[1].
However, because policies don't map 1:1 with APIs, it will not be
possible to fully document the policies until changes are made in how
policies are applied as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/528021

Due to the fact that existing policy files may rely on a rule named
"default" to specifiy policies not explicitly listed in the policy.json
file, all policies that are not admin-only by default now default to
"rule:default", so that the "default" rule will continue to apply to
those policies that are not listed in policy.json.

To ensure that this yields the expected policy in a standard
policy-in-code config file, the default value of the "default" rule is
now the empty string "". This is a change; between the Queens release
and now the default was set to "role:admin" to match the value specified
in the default policy.json file. An installation relying on both the
"default" rule for some policies and the default value of the default
rule may end up with a more permissive policy after upgrading. It's
likely that no such policies exist in the wild, because prior to the
Queens release the default value for the "default" rule was "@" (allow
all requests), so anybody relying on this rule will surely have
specified it explicitly in their policy.json.

Policies whose default is "role:admin" no longer use the "default" rule.
Therefore existing policy.json files that rely on the "default" rule for
those policies, and who have specified a value for the "default" rule
that is more permissive, will result in a more restrictive policy after
upgrading. It is unlikely that any of these policies exist in the wild
either.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/queens/policy-in-code.html

Change-Id: I8d1ccf5844078cc0b1652fb1130794daf07cedbc

commit_message:
Add new validation_json callback

This callback converts all events into a JSON output file and push it in
/var/log/validations.

Depends-On: I502c38d3f27db3c6f62a47190136dd03627956bc
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2020-01-07 17:12:04.000000000', 'message': 'Re-enable the n-cauth required service for stable/queens|pike|ocata

n-cauth serviec has been remvoed from nvoa in Ussuri and that is why
it was removed from default services[1]. But that is requried
for stable/queens|pike|ocata which still depends on text-matrix
for ENABLED_SERVICES. Since stable/rocky we have migrated the
service enable in devstack base job[2].

This commit fix the Tempest master and stable/queens|pike|ocata
gate by re-enable the n-cauth service for listed stable branches
only. Later we can discuss to remove the test-matrix dependency for
these branches also.

Related-Bug: 1858666
[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700217/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/546765/

Change-Id: Ia85ea5d338f07cb248f60de44b21826862d09d26
'}]
commit_message:
Re-enable the n-cauth required service for stable/queens|pike|ocata

n-cauth serviec has been remvoed from nvoa in Ussuri and that is why
it was removed from default services[1]. But that is requried
for stable/queens|pike|ocata which still depends on text-matrix
for ENABLED_SERVICES. Since stable/rocky we have migrated the
service enable in devstack base job[2].

This commit fix the Tempest master and stable/queens|pike|ocata
gate by re-enable the n-cauth service for listed stable branches
only. Later we can discuss to remove the test-matrix dependency for
these branches also.

Related-Bug: 1858666
[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700217/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/546765/

Change-Id: Ia85ea5d338f07cb248f60de44b21826862d09d26

commit_message:
Fix unittest test_router_update_gateway_upon_subnet_create_max_ips_ipv6

The change [1] modified the IP address from 2001:db8::1 to 2001:db8::.

We need to follow it in our unittests to unlock our
gates.

Unfortunately cover job installs Neutron from pip, so that this
test will continuously fail until new Neutron will be released.
We will not merge anything to networking-ovn repository, except
last OVN Octavia Provider Driver changes,  so I belive we can
set the cover job as non-voting.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699465/

Change-Id: I6bfa8f2ce30b2c4de4f5f33dc0599f709b9ce967

commit_message:
Support for Router Scheduling on addition/removal of chassis

The following patch provides L3HA Rescheduling of gateways when chassis
are added/removed. It reschedules the gateway ports when a new chassis
is added/old one removed. However, the number of chassis where a
gateway can be hosted is limited by the constant MAX_GW_CHASSIS.

Co-Authored-By: Maciej J√≥zefczyk <mjozefcz@redhat.com>

Conflicts:
   networking_ovn/tests/functional/base.py
   networking_ovn/tests/functional/test_router.py
   networking_ovn/l3/l3_ovn_scheduler.py

Change-Id: I0d96efe4ceef4168039930738285c19d5c003951
Closes-Bug: #1762691
(cherry picked from commit 12070403db4851ef73011c52124cd335b6807521)

commit_message:
Don't use eventlet.monkey_patch under wsgi

This causes errors and is not recommended.
It also solves the problem of coordination not
working properly under wsgi

Change-Id: Ie3052d8cdc047f8a46e139f533a63f8c36d2906d
Closes-Bug: 18008953

commit_message:
Impovements to additional cellv2 documentation

Fixes a statement in 'Configuring AZs for Nova' in relation to
multiple cells.
Other improvements to creating and managing cells.

Change-Id: I1724eadfe572732aca1425435d3a08cdf7f7ecac

commit_message:
Adding a new tag for launchpad

This tag is intend to be used by third party dependences such as libpod
and ceph-ansible that are not under openstack umbrella.

Change-Id: I8402c238e642244a13fee48182fb56119a80dc8f

commit_message:
Run update without yum update to apply hotfixes.

Add a new option to skip the yum update of all packages.

Change-Id: Idd22c7b4403bb63c06d2ba714d851a976e830108
(cherry picked from commit 4cc2b1196e2ac13de521b2fae0d1436a6f7d0d66)

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I73f57c423dfacdb67d9e06de2885943d800f47a9

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

commit_message:
Fix inventory and bionic dnsmasq start

The inventory was not firing up for python3 as ansible silently
conceals the inventory processing failure.

commit_message:
Change install-scripts for py3 with Ubuntu

Reworked the pip install logic so that we run the pypi
pip installer instead of trying to navigate through running
a pip install and upgrade with setuptools additionally.

These steps were orginally only done in order to force
us to a pip version >= 9.0.1, which is now the default
for Ubuntu Bionic.

Change-Id: Ic3a95973338bbd03061d5b3e4080c0d72d6b891a

subject: Skip status code check and make vagrant install quicker
messages: [{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-03 23:58:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-07 04:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-07 14:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2020-01-08 09:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:31:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-01-09 11:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\n(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-03 23:58:32.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Hopefully the last patch to fix ubuntu for python3

Change-Id: Icf132b71b243f9fce9d1c2afca656299befcfabc
'}, {'created': '2020-01-07 04:22:38.000000000', 'message': 'Skip status code check and make vagrant install quicker

Under some failure conditions, the status code is not returned.

Also skip the agent/os build steps for install inside of vagrant
which can add a substantial amount of time to the build process.

And minor revision to the test-bifrost.yaml conditional as the
pattern was traditionally "is defined", but when running the test
scripts, most things are defined, so it was just a side effect of
changes being purely tested in CI over time.

Change-Id: Icf132b71b243f9fce9d1c2afca656299befcfabc
'}, {'created': '2020-01-07 14:52:18.000000000', 'message': 'Skip status code check and make vagrant install quicker

Under some failure conditions, the status code is not returned.

Also skip the agent/os build steps for install inside of vagrant
which can add a substantial amount of time to the build process.

And minor revision to the test-bifrost.yaml conditional as the
pattern was traditionally "is defined", but when running the test
scripts, most things are defined, so it was just a side effect of
changes being purely tested in CI over time.

commit_message:
Skip status code check and make vagrant install quicker

Under some failure conditions, the status code is not returned.

Also skip the agent/os build steps for install inside of vagrant
which can add a substantial amount of time to the build process.

And minor revision to the test-bifrost.yaml conditional as the
pattern was traditionally "is defined", but when running the test
scripts, most things are defined, so it was just a side effect of
changes being purely tested in CI over time.

Change-Id: Icf132b71b243f9fce9d1c2afca656299befcfabc

commit_message:
Add ebtables to bindep

Required for CI testing, libvirt can raise errors about
not being able to initialize the firewall interface if ebtables
is not installed.

The same package name is used across distributions, so it is a nice
change for once.

Change-Id: I3738bb19345d59ab0c5175a9cfd99a91989bbfb6

commit_message:
Only perform OpenStack CI prep when in OpenStack ci

While ZUUL_BRANCH was not always being set, the way the roles and
playbooks were being executed the credential set action when locally
testing using test-bifrost.sh.

Change-Id: Iebe3937339572a1a21527fd7129a09dd05e0a8b7

commit_message:
Use pip3!

There are cases where we can fallback to using the pip command
instead of the pip module. This can result in some weird cases
like everything using python3, and then suddenly ironic being
installed with python2.

Change-Id: I7228535485d86bbddfc1fbec72006d9df9cd8c05

commit_message:
Python3 changes for Ubuntu

* Remove definitions for ubuntu 15.04 and 15.10
* Changed binary packages to the python3 package names.
* Removed python-configparser as it is no longer required

Change-Id: I8f102bb6ea6238a7f5a638b89f01dc16852fc741

commit_message:
Make a copy of requirements for local testers

The requirements repository is provided to us in most CI
testing scenarios, however we also want to force a constraint
upon installing python libraries for test VM creation dependencies.

As such lets at least get a copy of requirements up front when
testing with test-bifrost.sh or when using vagrant.

Change-Id: Ic6a5b8f7cdbf6f4c6233848bab1bfd71acc9d973

commit_message:
Explicitly set python interpreter for vagrant exec

Things get a little confusing for ansible and we changed the
main scripting to somewhat expect this when explicitly
executing the install playbook, as is in test-bifrost.sh.

Change-Id: I2bfea0e383387bf3c78359ffa8b98e4965ad3709

commit_message:
Drop using six library

Since we dropped python 2 support and testing in[1], there is
no compatibility with Python2 now. We can stop using python
six module.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698245/

Change-Id: I15771f129ada53f1f8ca6683c8d80d5675332db5

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I329e43d51aaeade8d4535b2f68cec7680b5ebfce

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

All the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I113c66802523de3ef64bdc08c61e7b2f36633dc3

subject: Introduce Ceph placement group validation
messages:
[{'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-12-20 19:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-12-20 19:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from ceph_pg-stable/train to ceph_pg'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2020-01-07 07:06:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

not sure how master passed though since this is cherrypick'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2020-01-07 07:07:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-07 14:53:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This patch fails openstack-tox-py27 [0] because of the order of the dicts:

  {'images': {'size': 3, 'pg_num': 128}}
  {'images': {'pg_num': 128, 'size': 3}}

The patch [1] this was cherry-picked from didn't have a openstack-tox-py27
test. I think py2 is having a side effect of changing the dict order which
is perfectly valid because the dict keys don't have to be in order. Thus,
the test shouldn't insist on a particular order.

In order to deal with this I've proposed an update [2] to the merged parent
to make the dict order not matter and update this patch directly with the
same change. Because I'll be making the same change directly in this patch
and it's relatives [3] all derivatives in train and older will be unclean
cherry picks.

So for now this is on hold until [2] merges.

[0] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/5f28defe0bbd40bb92359ae1a8311384
[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694673/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701367/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:ceph_pg"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > not sure how master passed though since this is cherrypick

This should now be addressed. Thanks for raising this.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-01-08 14:52:56.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from ceph_pg_train to ceph_pg'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2020-01-09 01:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2020-01-09 07:10:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)'}]

ceph-pg playbook and role.

Unclean cherry-pick includes https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701367

commit_message:
Release python-octaviaclient 2.0.0

This release includes new features, but is also the first release to
drop declared support for python 2.7. Because of this, we are bumping
the version to major 2.x.x.

Change-Id: I5848635655db82775ad375ec986f8ffa4980ca0a

commit_message:
Add namespaces to Ad-Hoc actions

 added namespace for the actions, actions can have the same name if they
 are not in the same namespace, when executing an action, if an action
 with that name is not found in the workflow namespace or given
 namespace mistral will look for that action in the default namespace.

  * action base can only be in the same namespace,or in the
    default namespace.
  * Namespaces are not part of the mistral DSL.
  * The default namespace is an empty string ''.
  * all actions will be in a namespace, if not specified, they will be
    under default namespace

Depends-On: I61acaed1658d291798e10229e81136259fcdb627
Change-Id: I07862e30adf28404ec70a473571a9213e53d8a08
Partially-Implements: blueprint create-and-run-workflows-within-a-namespace
Signed-off-by: ali <ali.abdelal@nokia.com>

'}, {'created': '2020-01-08 10:26:40.000000000', 'message': "Allow mysql haproxy stanza do be customized

We introduce a new tripleo::haproxy parameter called mysql_custom_listen_options
which can be used to customize mysql listen options in haproxy's config.

Tested as follows:
parameter_defaults:
  ExtraConfig:
    tripleo::haproxy::haproxy_default_timeout:
      - 'http-request 10s'
      - 'queue 2m'
      - 'connect 10s'
      - 'client 5m'
      - 'server 5m'
      - 'check 10s'
    tripleo::haproxy::cinder::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::glance_api::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::mysql_custom_listen_options:
      bind-process: 2

Observed that haproxy's mysql stanza had:
listen mysql
  bind 172.17.1.91:3306 transparent
  bind-process 2
  option tcpka
  option httpchk

Before this patch this was not the case and the tripleo::haproxy::<mysql>::options just got ignored.

Closes-Bug: #1858775

Change-Id: Ia0ecca5b54c1ca51898035e641665150dbdac9f7
"}]
commit_message:
Allow mysql haproxy stanza do be customized

We introduce a new tripleo::haproxy parameter called mysql_custom_listen_options
which can be used to customize mysql listen options in haproxy's config.

Tested as follows:
parameter_defaults:
  ExtraConfig:
    tripleo::haproxy::haproxy_default_timeout:
      - 'http-request 10s'
      - 'queue 2m'
      - 'connect 10s'
      - 'client 5m'
      - 'server 5m'
      - 'check 10s'
    tripleo::haproxy::cinder::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::glance_api::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::mysql_custom_listen_options:
      bind-process: 2

Observed that haproxy's mysql stanza had:
listen mysql
  bind 172.17.1.91:3306 transparent
  bind-process 2
  option tcpka
  option httpchk

Before this patch this was not the case and the tripleo::haproxy::<mysql>::options just got ignored.

Closes-Bug: #1858775

Change-Id: Ia0ecca5b54c1ca51898035e641665150dbdac9f7

commit_message:
Allow hiera overrides for logrotate params

Logrotate parameters, such as maxsize, need to be configurable via
hiera overrides as well.

Change-Id: Ib001f683ef6eec85e05362bd141fb354219f4259
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2019-12-15 01:15:08.000000000', 'message': '[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-mistralclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

python-mistralclient is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ia2e548105f06dfdd2dbabd425002ea1d4fe57f53

commit_message:
Pin gettext < 3.3.0

gettext-3.3.0 needs Ruby >= 2.5.0, which is not
available in CentOS7, so need to pin it.

messages:
[{'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2019-12-18 12:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2019-12-18 12:24:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2019-12-18 12:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-12-18 14:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hey Flavio, thanks for working on this, having it semi-automated is great!

I had a couple of questions, maybe we can discuss at our OVN meeting?

1. Where should this live?  I can see a case for the neutron repo since going forward we'll probably be fixing things there, then backporting to networking-ovn stable branches.

2. Would it be worth it to make it support a commit ID as an argument?  It could then use some git-fu (git whatchanged $ID -1) to get the files and create a patch from it, saving the step of the user creating a diff.

I wasn't "in the room" when it was added to the task list for migration, maybe others have thoughts on this too.'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-01-08 00:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-01-09 09:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Moved to neutron repo:  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701637/'}]

commit_message:
WIP: convert_helpers: migrating patches to/from neutron

This is a dry run attempt in making a script that can
take patches from networking-ovn and convert the file
names to what they are in the neutron repo.

The paths/names are currently hard coded, based on the
link:  https://ethercalc.openstack.org/networking-ovn-migration

Change-Id: I809b98c33261667037fd81b37ee5ddb625627b38

subject: Fix horizon dependency
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-09 09:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-09 09:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nAn example of the failure is http://zuul.openstack.org/build/38a17880fe774ffebb1fa016649c1f9c'}, {'account_id': 21224, 'date': '2020-01-09 09:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-09 09:03:49.000000000', 'message': "Fix horizon dependency

This commit moves horizon to requirements.txt.

horizon was added to uper-constraints in stable branches recently,
so installing from the tarball no longer works. upper-constraints
in stable branches picks up the right version of horizon, so there
is no need for the upper bound of the horizon version.

In addition, the link of the horizon tarball was not updated after
the stable branch was created. I don't know why it works for stable/train
but I believe this commit mitigates the situation as the upper-constraints
file in the requirements repo picks up the right version of horizon.

This commit is proposed directly as the similar change in the master
branch happened as part of Django 1.11 drop.

Change-Id: I6e2d30e91373e1cc742a4f3c02d32a90b714d7e4
"}]
commit_message:
Fix horizon dependency

This commit moves horizon to requirements.txt.

horizon was added to uper-constraints in stable branches recently,
so installing from the tarball no longer works. upper-constraints
in stable branches picks up the right version of horizon, so there
is no need for the upper bound of the horizon version.

In addition, the link of the horizon tarball was not updated after
the stable branch was created. I don't know why it works for stable/train
but I believe this commit mitigates the situation as the upper-constraints
file in the requirements repo picks up the right version of horizon.

This commit is proposed directly as the similar change in the master
branch happened as part of Django 1.11 drop.

Change-Id: I6e2d30e91373e1cc742a4f3c02d32a90b714d7e4

commit_message:
Add script for unit test coverage job

This patch will allow to run a non voting coverage job
which will detect any changes in the code coverage for
each commit on review.

Change-Id: Ie2bb1b23bb49f0f3b1a149b8e086c2a943f77508
Closes-Bug: 1655016

Choi', 'email': 'ianyrchoi@gmail.com', 'username': 'ianychoi'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24791, 'name': 'Maciej Jozefczyk', 'email': 'jeicam.pl@gmail.com', 'username': 'maciej.jozefczyk'}]

[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-23 11:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-23 11:47:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Waiting for an ACK to understand what's going on in here..."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-23 12:09:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

A systemic change is also introduced here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700427/ .'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-24 09:16:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

question: what happens if a foundation member changes their email address? I am not sure how we can handle it. Extra ATCs are usually not aware of the list here.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-24 13:12:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> question: what happens if a foundation member changes their email
 > address? I am not sure how we can handle it. Extra ATCs are usually
 > not aware of the list here.

Yes indeed.
We'll need to update that list in any case though, so I have commented just above a systemic change to ensure we are aware of things."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-01-06 10:13:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-06 10:31:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> We'll need to update that list in any case though, so I have commented just above a systemic change to ensure we are aware of things.

As you proposed in a different change, non-voting job looks fine.

I agree that we need to keep the ATC list up-to-date, but perhaps we need to clarify how to maintain the email list of extra ATCs. For example,

- When a foundation member changes their email address, who is responsible to update such address in the extra ATC list? PTL of a corresponding project?
- How long can we wait before removing it?

Immediate removal after changing a email address in the foundation web site sounds too aggressive. PTL ack would be fine."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-06 14:13:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > We'll need to update that list in any case though, so I have
 > commented just above a systemic change to ensure we are aware of
 > things.
 > 
 > As you proposed in a different change, non-voting job looks fine.
 > 
 > I agree that we need to keep the ATC list up-to-date, but perhaps
 > we need to clarify how to maintain the email list of extra ATCs.
 > For example,
 > 
 > - When a foundation member changes their email address, who is
 > responsible to update such address in the extra ATC list? PTL of a
 > corresponding project?
 > - How long can we wait before removing it?
 > 
 > Immediate removal after changing a email address in the foundation
 > web site sounds too aggressive. PTL ack would be fine.

Yes I agree that PTL of the project (on which we update the project metadata) should vote on this.
I do not see a reason to hold a patch though, or a need to change the policy (I think common sense applies...). But if you would be more comfortable with a policy change, this could be listed in governance house rules. Do you really want one? :)"}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2020-01-06 19:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am still checking with some active translators whether 1) they intentionally changed from Foundation member to Community member, 2) they changed the e-mail addresses on www.openstack.org/profile so that there was mismatch between the API result and the current extra-ATC list, and/or other possible cases.. thank you

> Yes I agree that PTL of the project (on which we update the project metadata) should vote on this.'}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2020-01-06 21:21:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-07 01:23:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Foundation memberships time out if you fail to vote in 2 consecutive board elections. It's likely that somebody cleaned out the inactive members in order to determine the electorate in advance of the upcoming board elections. (They really should do it immediately after an election, not immediately before the next one, since as we see here it affects other things too.)"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-07 08:57:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Foundation memberships time out if you fail to vote in 2
 > consecutive board elections. It's likely that somebody cleaned out
 > the inactive members in order to determine the electorate in
 > advance of the upcoming board elections. (They really should do it
 > immediately after an election, not immediately before the next one,
 > since as we see here it affects other things too.)

That's correct, and is indeed what happened. In this one, we are removing the ones that need removing."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-07 08:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-07 09:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I have reinstated the member that got re-active.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2020-01-07 09:02:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-01-07 10:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-01-07 12:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Looks correct to me
https://openstackid-resources.openstack.org/api/public/v1/members?&filter[]=group_slug==foundation-members&filter[]=email==andi@gowling.com,email==tfu@redhat.com,email==gang.sungjin@gmail.com,email==froms2008@gmail.com'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-07 12:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-07 14:33:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Keep in mind that our technical (TC, PTL) election tooling will still prevent them from getting a ballot if there is no corresponding active membership for them at the time we generate electoral rolls, so an informational check (maybe a separate non-voting job just to validate these) would be perfectly safe to prevent blocking governance changes. You could (if you haven't already) also scope the job to only run against changes to the projects.yaml file since that's the only place we track extra-ATCs."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2020-01-09 08:15:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Keep in mind that our technical (TC, PTL) election tooling will
 > still prevent them from getting a ballot if there is no
 > corresponding active membership for them at the time we generate
 > electoral rolls, so an informational check (maybe a separate
 > non-voting job just to validate these) would be perfectly safe to
 > prevent blocking governance changes. You could (if you haven't
 > already) also scope the job to only run against changes to the
 > projects.yaml file since that's the only place we track extra-ATCs.

I haven't filtered on the file. I thought it would be good to know when things change, to avoid the surprise when the time has come. Though, I would expect it's better in the case we filter with files to make the job voting. Else there is no reason to keep the job :p"}]

commit_message:
Remove incorrectly updated ATCs

In the previous ATC update, we modified the date of the members,
without checking that they could be ATCs. Because these emails are
not registered within the foundation, we should remove them.

Change-Id: I4634314e8cddad66f9866e95b2ffc136172b28cb

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

specs repo either has py27 job or requirement or tox env.

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ia6d4378abf5ee92f371236a081b82157a9c88682

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-07 06:48:08.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly enable ipxe as boot interface when it's enabled in the gate

Explicitly use ipxe interface when IRONIC_IPXE_ENABLED=True,
this needs to be done for ipxe changes in the ussuri when
upgrading from train to ussuri.

Change-Id: I30251c1261853e6d77bbf6cb6265a5a034a8c931
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly enable ipxe as boot interface when it's enabled in the gate

Explicitly use ipxe interface when IRONIC_IPXE_ENABLED=True,
this needs to be done for ipxe changes in the ussuri when
upgrading from train to ussuri.

Change-Id: I30251c1261853e6d77bbf6cb6265a5a034a8c931

commit_message:
Explicitly use ipxe as boot interface for iPXE testing

We are about to drop pxe + ipxe_enabled=True combination for iPXE
testing, so let's make it explicit in the jobs.

Change-Id: I0e99e6336aa47857c06ba2f6869e66580159a9be
Story: 2007003
Task: 37779

Functional jobs are taking more than double the time when compared to what has been average times (6-9 minutes in CI). The patch creates all sorts of valid and invalid combinations between listeners and pools. The feature is valid and the tests seem okay at first look, it's just the creation times that are unexpectedly way higher. We need to have a good look at what is going on."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-03-07 23:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 36.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-03-07 23:20:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 36:

commit_message:
Add listener and pool protocol validation

The pool and listener can't be combined arbitrarily. We need to add
some constraints in protocol side.

Story: 2003500
Tasks: 24777

Co-Authored-By: Carlos Goncalves <cgoncalves@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ifed862639d3fc3de23ace4c7ceaea1a4eca62749

messages: [{'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2020-01-08 21:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-08 21:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nConfusingly, `openstack limits show --absolute` reports maxTotalCores=128 and totalCoresUsed=80 (so nodepool is booting 5 instances of the os.extra.large.infra flavor) but it still complains that node requests would put it at a negative remaining cores quota.'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2020-01-09 00:55:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-01-09 07:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Revert "Linaro London: use new bigger flavour"

linaro-london got new Ceph setup so we can go back to 8vcpu per node.

This reverts commit 1900f336f732eb021719ffd68131d607dc0052bf.

Change-Id: I2e70dd03600e5168eb47d7d2fff2f1c364f0f301

messages: [{'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2020-01-01 20:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to drop-django111-support'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-01-09 06:57:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-01 20:57:34.000000000', 'message': 'Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2.
requirements.txt is updated accordingly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
Change-Id: I8f97ac0e749c6c108d809f246b044ba3e8a0010d
'}]
commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2.
requirements.txt is updated accordingly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
Change-Id: I8f97ac0e749c6c108d809f246b044ba3e8a0010d

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: I5ddd9d5ba23634f110927e385550d97b66fd2542

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: I59e016fd771282798bd095c562e2fa11a8e4ea43

[{'created': '2019-07-20 17:50:54.000000000', 'message': "Run 'tempest-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only'(adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6 and run smoke
tests and IPv6 related tests present in Tempest.

This job will be part of Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Keystone, Glance, Swift
gate.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'tempest-ipv6-only' will run the smoke + IPv6 related test case.

This commit adds the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only' run on gate.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35891

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: Ibe2c01713df2bec366c49d6e41b65b818b5e98e8
"}]
commit_message:
Run 'tempest-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only'(adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6 and run smoke
tests and IPv6 related tests present in Tempest.

This job will be part of Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Keystone, Glance, Swift
gate.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'tempest-ipv6-only' will run the smoke + IPv6 related test case.

This commit adds the new job 'tempest-ipv6-only' run on gate.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35891

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: Ibe2c01713df2bec366c49d6e41b65b818b5e98e8

[{'created': '2019-12-25 03:22:05.000000000', 'message': "Rebuild initramfs always after applying Sysctl

In LP#1830574, we introduce the dracut command to include necessary
file into initramfs. However, dracut in RHEL or CentOS doesn't include
sysctl.conf at an installation of new kernel. We should run dracut
after appling sysctl in every time.

Change-Id: I7fde9c07812a095d3a48c444d20c9574ed0c417d
Closes-bug: #1857493
"}]
commit_message:
Rebuild initramfs always after applying Sysctl

In LP#1830574, we introduce the dracut command to include necessary
file into initramfs. However, dracut in RHEL or CentOS doesn't include
sysctl.conf at an installation of new kernel. We should run dracut
after appling sysctl in every time.

Change-Id: I7fde9c07812a095d3a48c444d20c9574ed0c417d
Closes-bug: #1857493

[{'created': '2019-09-11 05:19:10.000000000', 'message': "[train][goal] Define new 'zaqar-tempest-redis-ipv6' job

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
we need to define the integration job which deploy services
on IPv6 and perform testing to make sure service listen and communicate
over IPv6 properly.

Zaqar has legacy zuul jobs so base zuulv3 IPv6 job 'devstack-ipv6' and
'devstack-tempest-ipv6' cannot be used and we have to copy the whole
run.yaml to set the IPv6 setting.

This commit adds the new job 'zaqar-tempest-redis-ipv6'
run on gate and set the required IPv6 setting'.

Change-Id: I9aece13783a061c4214157c3f7cfc9cc9f2a3f96
Story: #2005477
Task: #35941

commit_message:
[train][goal] Define new 'zaqar-tempest-swift-ipv6' job

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
we need to define the integration job which deploy services
on IPv6 and perform testing to make sure service listen and communicate
over IPv6 properly.

Zaqar has legacy zuul jobs so base zuulv3 IPv6 job 'devstack-ipv6' and
'devstack-tempest-ipv6' cannot be used and we have to copy the whole
run.yaml to set the IPv6 setting and run the IPv6 verification
script via post_test_hook.

This commit adds the new job 'zaqar-tempest-swift-ipv6'
run on gate and set the required IPv6 setting'.

Change-Id: I9aece13783a061c4214157c3f7cfc9cc9f2a3f96
Story: #2005477
Task: #35941

commit_message:
CI: make the metalsmith job voting and gating

This job is the only job that is currently testing partition images
with local boot. Due to its usage of a custom centos instance image,
there is some potential instability, but recent runs [1] have been
reliably green.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/builds?job_name=metalsmith-integration-glance-localboot-centos7

Change-Id: Iefbf94754da58c130eccba6fa24efac684ee4b41

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-05 13:57:44.000000000', 'message': 'Use errors="ignore" instead of skip

This will fix the following deprecation warning in ansible 2.8:

[DEPRECATION WARNING]: Use errors="ignore" instead of skip. This feature
will be removed in version 2.12. Deprecation warnings can be disabled by
setting deprecation_warnings=False in ansible.cfg.

This patch should be backported to train and other releases where
ansible 2.8 is used.

On master, it could be reverted once it merges, b/c the skip option has
now been undeprecated in later ansible releases:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/60161

Change-Id: Ife6ab6359bd07b854441c13f3d0387a0a493f0ed
'}]
commit_message:
Use errors="ignore" instead of skip

This will fix the following deprecation warning in ansible 2.8:

[DEPRECATION WARNING]: Use errors="ignore" instead of skip. This feature
will be removed in version 2.12. Deprecation warnings can be disabled by
setting deprecation_warnings=False in ansible.cfg.

This patch should be backported to train and other releases where
ansible 2.8 is used.

On master, it could be reverted once it merges, b/c the skip option has
now been undeprecated in later ansible releases:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/60161

Change-Id: Ife6ab6359bd07b854441c13f3d0387a0a493f0ed

commit_message:
Drop django-babel from requirement.txt

We have switched the babel extractor for Django from django-babel
to enmerkar recently. murano-dashboard requirements.txt needs to
sync the change. enmerkar, a successor of django-babel will be
installed via horizon, so we don't need to have it in requirements.txt
explicitly.

lower-constrants.txt is updated to use enmerkar accordingly.

Change-Id: Iab0a50a6f6546d3d67d0e9b00f9bbd04ee2f6c7c

We have switched the babel extractor for Django from django-babel
to enmerkar recently. solum-dashboard requirements.txt needs to
sync the change. enmerkar, a successor of django-babel will be

explicitly.

commit_message:
Remove the condition that the mtu is nullable

The mtu is already non-nullable, it no longer needs to
judge the mtu when updating the network.
Related-Bug: #1842261

Change-Id: Ic097bc2ae50198a3bda45e4a8161c22190ef1964

commit_message:
Remove PreNetworkConfig resource

PreNetworkConfig resource was required to support host changes
before network deployment (for OvS-DPDK). As the required steps
has been migrated to ansible deploy_steps with 'step: 0', this
resources is no longer required.

Change-Id: I11a8ec280b4f5c33b6061a96cb546b4760a45b3a

messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-07 20:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-01-08 07:07:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I guess it's mostly the listing of extensions which are expensive when cache is disabled which is the default.

We don't have it enabled for undercloud heat, but I think this is part of the large scale deployment guide and have not seen any issues being reported yet."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-08 15:44:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow+1

Yeah, it could be that it's mostly the extensions that are expensive (in theory at least we only need to get the catalog once per request, but it can't hurt to cache the results at this level). It could also be that TripleO isn't using many/any of the resource types that require extensions."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}]

[{'created': '2020-01-07 17:26:57.000000000', 'message': "Cache service availability results per request

Retrieving the list of available resource types seems to be inordinately
slow on at least some clouds (though not in our gate tests). It appears
that checking service availability is the main culprit. These service
availability checks are also performed during validation of a template,
so they should be as fast as possible.

Previously, we never cached the availability of a service, probably on
the assumption that checking the catalog, once retrieved, would be
quick. It's not clear that we even need to use the user's token to
retrieve the catalog on each request, since all users should see the
same catalog. However, at a minimum we can cache the results for the
request so that we don't need to do multiple lookups of the same service
when validating a single stack or listing the available resource types.
This patch does that, and also caches the results of extension lookups
in Neutron and Cinder for the duration of the request, independently of
the global oslo.cache settings (which, if enabled, can cache the results
across requests).

Change-Id: I0618dc2a35f7323abedccb13ef3d6537eef1d24c
Task: 37974

Task: 37974
"}]
commit_message:
Cache service availability results per request

Retrieving the list of available resource types seems to be inordinately
slow on at least some clouds (though not in our gate tests). It appears
that checking service availability is the main culprit. These service
availability checks are also performed during validation of a template,
so they should be as fast as possible.

Previously, we never cached the availability of a service, probably on
the assumption that checking the catalog, once retrieved, would be
quick. It's not clear that we even need to use the user's token to
retrieve the catalog on each request, since all users should see the
same catalog. However, at a minimum we can cache the results for the
request so that we don't need to do multiple lookups of the same service
when validating a single stack or listing the available resource types.
This patch does that, and also caches the results of extension lookups
in Neutron and Cinder for the duration of the request, independently of
the global oslo.cache settings (which, if enabled, can cache the results
across requests).

Change-Id: I0618dc2a35f7323abedccb13ef3d6537eef1d24c
Task: 37974

commit_message:
Add check-requirements to project template

This patch adds a job to check the requirements in the gate.
To pass the test, this patch includes several fixes:

* Revert following commits:
    - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671249
      (baaaff17b5a57347cc19a896040d8c3ddd6fe8b1)
* Add missing packages in lower-constraints.txt
    - osprofiler
    - setuptools
* Adjust psycopg2 version in test-requirements.txt
  to that in lower-constraints.txt.
  This has been bumped in:
    - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/614559/.
      (4469a813cb68d99b81440dd33f5f7e9a1f892c27)

Change-Id: Ib9942a8310a74bf48a2b05a78a4971cba87d7689
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698960
Story: #2007023
Task: #37813

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit 1.6.0 & cap sphinx for 2.7

The latest version of bandit has broken directory exclusion,
so multiple test files are getting flagged. This change
blocks version 1.6.0 while this issue is fixed for 1.6.1.

This change also caps sphinx at <2.0.0 for python version 2.7.

Change-Id: I5d32d835886360522af21f735c74b2f85036f7f1

See if this fixes the docs gate issue

Change-Id: Ib2c74f4f37855cec250d09b23c45b5b7fde44c8d
'}, {'created': '2019-08-23 19:04:24.000000000', 'message': 'Comment html_static_path entry in docs conf.py

Currently with sphinx 2.2.0 the docs job is throwing a warning
that the html_static_path entry does not exist. We treat warnings
as errors so this causes the job to fail.

This change comments the html_static_path entry in conf.py since
the path currently does not exist so it appears to be unused.

Change-Id: Ib2c74f4f37855cec250d09b23c45b5b7fde44c8d
'}]
commit_message:
Comment html_static_path entry in docs conf.py

Currently with sphinx 2.2.0 the docs job is throwing a warning
that the html_static_path entry does not exist. We treat warnings
as errors so this causes the job to fail.

This change comments the html_static_path entry in conf.py since
the path currently does not exist so it appears to be unused.

Change-Id: Ib2c74f4f37855cec250d09b23c45b5b7fde44c8d

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-13 16:27:30.000000000', 'message': 'Handle log message interpolation by the logger in volume/

According to OpenStack Guideline[1], logged string message should be
interpolated by the logger. Also, the corresponding unit tests are
fixed to check the new kind of call.

[1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#adding-variables-to-log-messages

commit_message:
Handle log message interpolation by the logger in volume/

According to OpenStack Guideline[1], logged string message should be
interpolated by the logger. Also, the corresponding unit tests are
fixed to check the new kind of call.

[1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#adding-variables-to-log-messages

Change-Id: Idef02d7d5443925a5422aaee1145860fb1ba0fce
Related-Bug: #1596829

Added `--overcloud-ssh-enable-timeout` and
`--overcloud-ssh-port-timeout` to the openstack overcloud deploy command
to allow users the ability to tune these values.  The ssh port timeout
might need to be tuned if the hardware being deployed is slow to post
and takes longer than 5 minutes to become ready.

These options have been added to:

 * openstack overcloud deploy
 * openstack overcloud admin
 * openstack overcloud ffu upgrade
 * openstack overcloud upgrade

Change-Id: I56f6001b5efeed7ccb3918a5c2622c3eca613c07
Closes-Bug: #1858222

'}]
commit_message:
Add additional ssh timeout options

Added `--overcloud-ssh-enable-timeout` and
`--overcloud-ssh-port-timeout` to the openstack overcloud deploy command
to allow users the ability to tune these values.  The ssh port timeout
might need to be tuned if the hardware being deployed is slow to post
and takes longer than 5 minutes to become ready.

These options have been added to:

 * openstack overcloud deploy
 * openstack overcloud admin
 * openstack overcloud ffu upgrade
 * openstack overcloud upgrade

Change-Id: I56f6001b5efeed7ccb3918a5c2622c3eca613c07
Closes-Bug: #1858222
(cherry picked from commit 188acfbc40448278084bc05ee8d4ad7ecc61905a)

commit_message:
Fix workaround delegation when overcloud's name is not overcloud.

tripleo-ansible-inventory use overcloud as the name of the stack by
default.  On some ci, that value may be different, this then produces
an undercloud only inventory file.

Change-Id: Ic420c0717165e01df99ad2368a23fc9fc10e71c1
Closes-Bug: #1857120
(cherry picked from commit 6483436d7d0916e5e07fa38b9041e0fd7a5dde1f)
(cherry picked from commit 1da968309d1ee8a12f1cfc4a9399eba6df4b8be8)

commit_message:
Set default api version for global options

Each client object's global option "--os-xxx-api-version"
should be set to DEFAULT_API_VERSION.

Change-Id: I5e09833022bfa825ecc2a7039b7fe5ec4718cb44

We have another ARM cloud - will this change now lead to a situation where it works in Linaro London but fails in the other?'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-07-18 11:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> We have another ARM cloud - will this change now lead to a

There is such risk. 

Zuul nodes page did not listed other arm64 machines than linaro-london ones.'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-07-23 11:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ping?'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-07-23 13:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is this mainly for the additional processor capacity, or do Kolla jobs really use twice as much RAM when run on ARM64 AArch64 instead of AMD64 x86/64.'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-07-23 15:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Is this mainly for the additional processor capacity, or do Kolla
 > jobs really use twice as much RAM when run on ARM64 AArch64 instead
 > of AMD64 x86/64.

More cpu capacity. Ram amount is not that crucial.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-07-23 16:20:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If you have a flavor with the desired CPU but only 8GB RAM, that could help maintain consistency with our other environments (alternatively, in the past we've used a kernel command-line parameter in the guest image's bootloader configuration to artificially limit the amount of RAM in providers which did not provide a suitably memory-limited flavor)."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-07-23 19:59:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> If you have a flavor with the desired CPU but only 8GB RAM, that
 > could help maintain consistency with our other environments
 > (alternatively, in the past we've used a kernel command-line
 > parameter in the guest image's bootloader configuration to
 > artificially limit the amount of RAM in providers which did not
 > provide a suitably memory-limited flavor).

Yes, I think we should increase the CPU count without bumping the memory size. Our restricted environments are that way for a reason (aids with local reproduction wtihout expecting developers to have a datacenter or special hardware). It has also been a major benefit to the edge work because we already run and test on constricted envs.

In the past we used the kernel parameter because the cloud would not create new flavors for us, I expect that won't be a problem in this case?"}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-07-24 09:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK. Contacted Kevin Zhao to prepare 16vpu 8gb flavour.

Thanks for suggestion.'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2019-07-29 05:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

just use this flavor. This has been set to 16C 8G now'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-07-29 06:30:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks - Then let's update the commit message to reflect what we do."}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-07-31 09:23:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-07-31 10:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-07-31 10:53:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The new flavor doesn't set ephemeral, I think we need that 80G volume for swap and /opt?"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-07-31 10:56:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2019-08-05 14:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2019-08-06 11:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

modified to 16C 8G 80G and 80G ephemeral storage now'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-08-08 16:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-08 16:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2020-01-08 21:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as I2e70dd03600e5168eb47d7d2fff2f1c364f0f301'}]

commit_message:
Linaro London: use new bigger flavour

Kolla CI jobs are unable to fit in 3h timeout on current instances so 
we created new flavour with twice cpu power (16vcpu instead of 8).

Change-Id: I32511c0253418f1b3ae6a59985ec5df0cb2c3ec1

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-07 19:28:51.000000000', 'message': 'Make tests pass in 2022

Background:
As part of my work on reproducible builds for openSUSE, I check that software still gives identical build results in the future.
The usual offset is +15 years, because that is how long I expect some software will be used in some places.
This showed up failing tests in our package build.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

This makes it expire 1 year in the future to model realistic tokens.

Change-Id: I73bde68be53afff4e8dff12d756b8381f34b2adb
(cherry picked from commit 4a4c96ce9b28ed54f93a21ca405c5b34ef3c3429)
'}]
commit_message:
Make tests pass in 2022

Background:
As part of my work on reproducible builds for openSUSE, I check that software still gives identical build results in the future.
The usual offset is +15 years, because that is how long I expect some software will be used in some places.
This showed up failing tests in our package build.
See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

This makes it expire 1 year in the future to model realistic tokens.

Change-Id: I73bde68be53afff4e8dff12d756b8381f34b2adb
(cherry picked from commit 4a4c96ce9b28ed54f93a21ca405c5b34ef3c3429)

commit_message:
Make tests pass in 2020

This issue was found while working on reproducible builds for openSUSE.

This solves it similar to change I73bde68be53afff4e8dff12d756b8381f34b2adb

Changed month to February to avoid races around new year.

Change-Id: I2a28f3f4eaabaa772df395f3f5d55b6fd78f8968
(cherry picked from commit 4461358098cbbe3ce27f05801ae06b191b092d05)
